Sub_topics.description: Use non-calculator methods to calculate the sum, difference, product and quotient of positive and negative whole numbers (integers).
Understand and use the terms odd, even, prime, factor (divisor), multiple, common factor (divisor), common multiple, square, cube, root; understand and use place value (for whole numbers).

Identify prime numbers less than 20; express a whole number as a product of its prime factors (e.g. 24 = 2×2×2×3); understand that each whole number can be expressed as a product of prime factors in only one way (unique factorisation). Higher-tier extension: identify prime numbers (not restricted to <20) and use index/power notation in prime factorisation (e.g. 600 = 2^3 × 3 × 5^2).

Find the Highest Common Factor (HCF) and Lowest Common Multiple (LCM) of two whole numbers by listing. Foundation-tier extension: find HCF and LCM of two whole numbers from their prime factorisations (using prime powers).
Know the conventional order for performing calculations involving brackets, the four rules (+, −, ×, ÷), and powers/indices, roots and reciprocals (BIDMAS/PEMDAS idea).

Know that addition/subtraction, multiplication/division, and powers/roots are inverse operations; use inverses to simplify and check calculations, including reversing arithmetic in contexts such as “I’m thinking of a number” and “missing digit” problems (e.g. 223 − 98 = 223 + 2 − 100; 25×12 = 50×6 = 100×3).
Recognise and use equivalence between simple fractions and mixed numbers (convert between improper fractions and mixed numbers), e.g. 6/3 = 2 and 5/2 = 2 1/2.

Add, subtract, multiply and divide simple fractions (proper and improper), including mixed numbers and negative fractions; e.g. 1 1/2 + 3/4, (5/6)×(3/10), −3×(4/5). Higher-tier extension: carry out more complex fraction calculations, including use of improper fractions as a standard method; links to algebraic fractions (6.01g).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Fractions of a quantity and fraction comparisons
Sub_topics.description: Calculate a fraction of a quantity (including in money contexts), e.g. 2/5 of £3.50; express one quantity as a fraction of another (part/whole). Higher-tier extension: calculate with fractions greater than 1 in quantity contexts. (Also connects to ratios and fractions 5.01c.)

Express a simple fraction as a terminating decimal or vice versa without a calculator (e.g. 0.4 = 2/5); understand and use place value in decimals. Foundation-tier extension: use division to convert a simple fraction to a decimal including recurring results (e.g. 1/6 = 0.1666…); Higher-tier extension: convert a recurring decimal to an exact fraction or vice versa (e.g. 0.41̇ = 41/99 type conversions as appropriate).
Add, subtract and multiply decimals including negative decimals, without a calculator (correct alignment of decimal places; handling of signs).
Divide a decimal by a whole number, including negative decimals, without a calculator (e.g. 0.24 ÷ 6). Foundation-tier extension: without a calculator, divide a decimal by a decimal (e.g. 0.3 ÷ 0.6).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Convert between fractions, decimals and percentages
Sub_topics.description: Convert between fractions, decimals and percentages, e.g. 1/4 = 0.25 = 25% and 1 1/2 = 150%.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Percentages of quantities and percentage of another
Sub_topics.description: Understand percentage as ‘number of parts per hundred’; calculate a percentage of a quantity; express one quantity as a percentage of another, with or without a calculator.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Percentage change, multipliers, original value and simple interest
Sub_topics.description: Increase or decrease a quantity by a simple percentage, including simple decimal or fractional multipliers; apply to simple original value problems and simple interest (e.g. add 10% to £2.50 by finding 10% then adding, or by multiplying by 1.1; find original price when reduced by 50%). Higher-tier extension: express percentage change as a decimal or fractional multiplier; apply to percentage change problems including original value problems; links to growth and decay (5.03a).
Order integers, fractions, decimals and percentages (including negatives where relevant), e.g. 4/5, 3/4, 0.72, −0.9.
Use the symbols <, >, ≤, ≥, =, ≠ correctly to compare numbers and express order/relationships.

Use positive integer indices to write repeated multiplication (e.g. 2×2×2×2 = 2^4). Foundation-tier extension: use negative integer indices to represent reciprocals (a^−n = 1/a^n). Higher-tier extension: use fractional indices to represent roots and combinations of powers and roots (e.g. a^(1/2)=√a, a^(m/n)=ⁿ√(a^m)).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Calculate and estimate powers and roots
Sub_topics.description: Calculate positive integer powers and exact roots (square roots, cube roots) exactly (e.g. 2^4=16, √9=3, ∛8=2). Foundation-tier extension: recognise simple powers of 2, 3, 4 and 5 (e.g. 27 = 3^3). Higher-tier extension: calculate with integer powers (including negatives), roots and fractional powers; estimate powers and roots (e.g. √51 to nearest whole number).

Know and apply index laws: a^m × a^n = a^(m+n); a^m ÷ a^n = a^(m−n); (a^m)^n = a^(mn); apply within numerical and algebraic contexts and connect to simplifying products/quotients (6.01c) and standard form calculations (3.02b).
Interpret and order numbers expressed in standard form; convert numbers to and from standard form, including positive and negative powers of 10 (e.g. 1320 = 1.32×10^3; 0.00943 = 9.43×10^−3).

Use a calculator to perform calculations with numbers in standard form. Higher-tier extension: add, subtract, multiply and divide numbers in standard form without a calculator, applying index laws (e.g. (a×10^m)(b×10^n) = (ab)×10^(m+n)).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Exact calculations using fractions, π and surds
Sub_topics.description: Use fractions in exact calculations without a calculator. Foundation-tier extension: use multiples of π in exact calculations without a calculator (leave answers in terms of π). Higher-tier extension: use surds in exact calculations without a calculator (leave answers in surd form).

Higher-tier only: simplify expressions involving surds (e.g. √12 = 2√3), perform operations with surds, and rationalise denominators (e.g. 1/√3 = √3/3; rationalising denominators of the form a + b√c as required).
Round numbers to the nearest whole number, 10, 100, etc., or to a given number of significant figures (sf) or decimal places (dp). Round answers to an appropriate level of accuracy in context.

Estimate or check, without a calculator, the result of a calculation by using suitable approximations (e.g. estimate cost of 2.8 kg at 68p/kg by rounding to 1 sf). Foundation-tier extension: estimate/check more complex calculations including roots; use the symbol ≈ appropriately.

Use inequality notation to write an error interval for a number/measurement rounded or truncated to a given accuracy (e.g. x=2.1 to 1 dp implies 2.05 ≤ x < 2.15; truncation gives 2.1 ≤ x < 2.2). Foundation-tier extension: apply and interpret limits of accuracy; calculate upper and lower bounds of a calculation when inputs are rounded to known accuracy (e.g. area with length and width to 2 sf); understand the difference between bounds for discrete and continuous quantities (e.g. 200 cars to nearest 100 gives 150 ≤ n < 250; but for discrete, n is integer so interpret appropriately).

Topics.Topic_name: Ratio, Proportion and Rates Of Change

Sub_topics.description: Find the ratio of quantities in the form a:b and simplify; find ratios in the form 1:n, including unit conversions within ratios (e.g. 50 cm : 1.5 m = 50 : 150 = 1 : 3).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Divide in a given ratio (2 parts and more)
Sub_topics.description: Split a quantity into two parts given the ratio of the parts (e.g. £2.50 in ratio 2:3). Foundation-tier extension: express a division of a quantity into two parts as a ratio; calculate one quantity from another given their ratio; split a quantity into three or more parts given the ratio.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ratios as fractions of a whole
Sub_topics.description: Interpret a ratio of two parts as a fraction of the whole (e.g. £9 split 2:1 gives 2/3×9 and 1/3×9). Connect ratio with fractions of a quantity (2.01c).
Solve simple ratio and proportion problems (e.g. scaling recipes). Foundation-tier extension: understand the relationship between ratio and linear functions (ratio reasoning as proportional scaling).

Solve problems involving quantities in direct proportion, including algebraic proportions using equality of ratios (e.g. if y ∝ x then y1/x1 = y2/x2). Include currency conversion problems. Foundation-tier extension: solve more formal direct proportion problems (recognise y = kx); Higher-tier extension: formulate equations and solve problems where one quantity is directly proportional to a power or root of another (e.g. y ∝ x^n or y ∝ √x).

Solve problems involving quantities in inverse proportion, including word problems and simple algebraic proportions (e.g. speed–time contexts where doubling speed halves time). Foundation-tier extension: solve more formal inverse proportion problems (recognise y = k/x); Higher-tier extension: formulate equations and solve problems where one quantity is inversely proportional to a power or root of another (e.g. y ∝ 1/x^n or y ∝ 1/√x).

Calculate simple interest including in financial contexts. Foundation-tier extension: solve step-by-step problems involving multipliers over a given interval (compound interest, depreciation etc.), e.g. sequential percentage changes over years. Higher-tier extension: express exponential growth/decay as a formula (e.g. A = 100×1.1^n); solve and interpret answers in growth/decay contexts; connect to percentage change multipliers (2.03c) and exponential graphs (7.01d).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Algebra language, equivalence, identities and proof
Sub_topics.description: Understand and use the concepts/vocabulary of expressions, equations, formulae, inequalities, terms and factors. Foundation-tier extension: recognise the difference between an equation and an identity; show algebraic expressions are equivalent (e.g. prove (x+1)^2 + 2 = x^2 + 2x + 3). Higher-tier extension: use algebra to construct arguments, proofs and generalisations (e.g. prove sum of three consecutive integers is a multiple of 3).
Simplify algebraic expressions by collecting like terms in sums and differences (e.g. 2a + 3a = 5a), including with negatives and multiple terms.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Algebraic products and quotients (incl. index laws)
Sub_topics.description: Simplify algebraic products and quotients (e.g. a×a×a = a^3; 2a×3b = 6ab; a^3 ÷ a = a^2). Foundation-tier extension: simplify using the laws of indices in algebraic contexts (e.g. a^2×a^3 = a^5; a^−1 = 1/a).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Expanding brackets (single bracket, two binomials, more)
Sub_topics.description: Expand/simplify algebraic expressions by multiplying a single term over a bracket (e.g. 2(a+3b)=2a+6b; 2(a+3b)+3(a−2b)=5a). Foundation-tier extension: expand products of two binomials (FOIL) (e.g. (x−1)(x−2)=x^2−3x+2; (a+2b)(a−b)=a^2+ab−2b^2). Higher-tier extension: expand products of more than two binomials (e.g. (x+1)(x−1)(x+2)).

Factorise by taking out common factors (e.g. 3a−9b = 3(a−3b); 2x+3x^2 = x(2+3x)). Foundation-tier extension: factorise quadratic expressions of the form x^2 + bx + c (e.g. x^2−x−6=(x−3)(x+2); x^2−16=(x−4)(x+4); x^2−3 = (x−√3)(x+√3) where applicable). Higher-tier extension: factorise quadratic expressions of the form ax^2 + bx + c where a ≠ 0 or 1 (e.g. 2x^2+3x−2 = (2x−1)(x+2)).

Higher-tier only: complete the square for a quadratic expression to rewrite in vertex form (e.g. x^2 + 4x − 6 = (x+2)^2 − 10), including when coefficient of x^2 is not 1 (e.g. 5/2 x^2 + x + 1/2). Use completed square form for solving/graph features where required.

Higher-tier only: simplify and manipulate algebraic fractions, including forming a single fraction from expressions (e.g. (n+1)/(n−1) + ...), simplifying rational expressions such as (n^2+2)/(n^2−2) type forms, and algebraic operations requiring factorisation and cancellation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Form algebraic expressions and formulae from contexts
Sub_topics.description: Formulate simple expressions and formulae from real-world contexts (e.g. cost = 50d + 0.10m; perimeter of rectangle when length is 2 cm more than width). Links to direct/inverse proportion (5.02a/5.02b) and growth/decay (5.03a).

Substitute numerical values into expressions and formulae to evaluate. Start with positive numbers in simple expressions and formulae (e.g. v = u + at). Foundation-tier extension: substitute positive or negative numbers into more complex formulae including powers, roots and algebraic fractions (e.g. v^2 = u^2 + 2as with decimal/negative inputs).

Rearrange formulae to change the subject when the subject appears once only (e.g. c = πd; y = 3x − 2). Foundation-tier extension: rearrange formulae where the subject appears twice, or where a power/reciprocal of the subject appears (e.g. s = 1/2 at^2; v = x/t; 2ty = t + 1), including cases involving algebraic fractions (6.01g).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Recall and use standard formulae (geometry and algebra)
Sub_topics.description: Recall and use standard formulae without a formula sheet: circumference of a circle C = 2πr = πd; area of a circle A = πr^2. Foundation-tier extension: recall and use Pythagoras’ theorem a^2 + b^2 = c^2; right-triangle trigonometry ratios sinθ = opposite/hypotenuse, cosθ = adjacent/hypotenuse, tanθ = opposite/adjacent. Higher-tier extension: recall and use the quadratic formula x = (−b ± √(b^2 − 4ac)) / (2a); sine rule a/sinA = b/sinB = c/sinC; cosine rule a^2 = b^2 + c^2 − 2bc cosA; area of a triangle = (1/2)ab sin C.

Use the kinematics equations for constant acceleration: v = u + at; s = ut + (1/2)at^2; v^2 = u^2 + 2as, where u is initial velocity, v final velocity, a constant acceleration, s displacement from position when t = 0, and t time taken. Knowledge of the physical meaning of each letter is not required, but learners must use and rearrange these formulae as mathematical relationships.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Solving linear equations in one unknown
Sub_topics.description: Solve linear equations in one unknown algebraically (e.g. 3x − 1 = 5). Foundation-tier extension: set up and solve linear equations in mathematical and non-mathematical contexts, including unknowns on both sides (e.g. 5(x−1)=4−x); interpret solutions in context, including situations involving algebraic fractions (6.01g).

Solve quadratic equations with coefficient of x^2 equal to 1 by factorising (e.g. x^2 − 5x + 6 = 0), including in context problems (area/geometry). Foundation-tier extension: know the quadratic formula; rearrange and solve quadratic equations by factorising, completing the square, or using the quadratic formula, including quadratics arising from algebraic fractions.

Set up and solve two linear simultaneous equations in two variables algebraically (e.g. 2x+3y=18 and y=3x−5). Foundation-tier extension: solve simultaneous equations where one equation is quadratic or where solving leads to a quadratic (e.g. x^2 + y^2 = 50 and y = 2x + 5).

Use a graph to find the approximate solution of a linear equation. Foundation-tier extension: use graphs to find approximate roots of quadratic equations and approximate solutions of two linear simultaneous equations. Higher-tier extension: know that intersection points of a curve and a straight line correspond to solutions of the simultaneous equations defining the line and curve.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Approximate solutions by iteration / numerical methods
Sub_topics.description: Higher-tier only: find approximate solutions to equations using systematic sign-change methods (e.g. decimal search, interval bisection) when no simple analytic method exists. Specific methods will not be explicitly requested, but learners must apply a valid iterative/sign-change approach and interpret solutions.

Understand and use inequality symbols <, ≤, >, ≥; solve linear inequalities in one variable and represent solution sets on a number line using conventional notation (e.g. 2x+1 < 7). Foundation-tier extension: solve quadratic inequalities in one variable (e.g. x^2 − 3x ≥ 2); express solutions in set-builder notation (e.g. {x | x < 3} or {x | −2 ≤ x < 5}).
Solve one or more linear inequalities in two variables and represent the solution set on a graph/coordinate plane as a region (including boundaries).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Functions as mappings; inverses and composites (informal)
Sub_topics.description: Interpret simple expressions as functions with inputs and outputs (e.g. y = 2x + 3 as a process ‘×2 then +3’). Foundation-tier extension: interpret the reverse process as an inverse function; interpret applying two functions in succession as a composite function. Formal function notation (f(x), f⁻¹(x), composite symbol) is not required, but concepts must be understood and applied.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sequences (term-to-term and nth term; arithmetic and quadratic)
Sub_topics.description: Generate a sequence by spotting a pattern or using a term-to-term rule given in words or algebra (e.g. 1,4,7,10,…; 1,4,9,16,…). Foundation-tier extension: find a position-to-term (nth term) rule for simple arithmetic sequences (e.g. 2,4,6,… is 2n; 3,4,5,… is n+2); generate terms from a given nth-term formula (e.g. n^2+2n gives 3,8,15,…); find a formula for nth term of an arithmetic sequence (e.g. 40,37,34,… is 43−3n); use subscript notation for sequences (u_n, x_n; e.g. x_n = 2n+… and x_{n+1}=x_n−3); Higher-tier extension: find a formula for the nth term of a quadratic sequence (e.g. u_n = 2n^2 − 3n + 1).

Recognise sequences of triangular, square and cube numbers and simple arithmetic progressions. Foundation-tier extension: recognise Fibonacci and quadratic sequences and simple geometric progressions of the form r^n where n is an integer and r is a rational number > 0; generate and find nth terms of other sequences, including those involving powers and reciprocals.
Work with x- and y-coordinates in all four quadrants, including reading, plotting and interpreting points (x, y) with positive and negative values.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Plotting graphs from tables (linear, quadratic, and more)
Sub_topics.description: Use a table of values to plot graphs of linear and quadratic functions (e.g. y = 2x + 3; y = 2x^2 + 1). Foundation-tier extension: use tables to plot other polynomial graphs and reciprocal graphs (e.g. y = x^3 − 2x; y = 1/(x+2); line 2x+3y=6), and plot exponential graphs using tables (e.g. y = 3×1.1^x).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sketching linear, quadratic, cubic and reciprocal graphs
Sub_topics.description: Recognise and sketch graphs of simple linear and quadratic functions (e.g. y=2, x=1, y=2x, y=x^2). Foundation-tier extension: recognise and sketch graphs of y=x^3 and y=1/x; identify intercepts and (using symmetry) the turning point of quadratic graphs; find roots of a quadratic equation algebraically. Higher-tier extension: sketch quadratic graphs identifying the turning point by completing the square.
Recognise and sketch graphs of exponential functions in the form y = k^x for positive k, including growth/decay behaviour and key intercept/shape features.
Higher-tier only: recognise and sketch the graphs of y = sin x, y = cos x and y = tan x, including periodicity and key values/intercepts/asymptotes for tan as appropriate.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Equation of a circle (centre at origin)
Sub_topics.description: Higher-tier only: recognise and use the equation of a circle with centre at the origin (x^2 + y^2 = r^2), including interpreting r and using it in coordinate geometry contexts.

Find and interpret the gradient and intercept of straight lines graphically and using y = mx + c. Foundation-tier extension: use y = mx + c to find and sketch equations of straight lines; find equation of a line through two points or through one point with given gradient; identify solution sets of linear inequalities in two variables using dashed/solid boundary lines.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Parallel and perpendicular lines; tangents to circles
Sub_topics.description: Foundation-tier extension: identify and find equations of parallel lines (same gradient). Higher-tier extension: identify and find equations of perpendicular lines (gradients m1·m2 = −1 where defined); calculate the equation of a tangent to a circle at a given point (link to circle equation x^2 + y^2 = r^2).

Identify and sketch translations and reflections of a given graph or of the graph of a given equation; e.g. sketch y = sin(x) + 2, y = 2(x+1)^2, y = −x^2. Formal function notation is not required, but learners must link geometric transformation to algebraic change.

Construct and interpret graphs in real-world contexts such as distance–time, money conversion and temperature conversion; Foundation-tier extension: recognise and interpret graphs that illustrate direct and inverse proportion.

Understand relationship between gradient and ratio; interpret straight-line gradients as rates of change (e.g. gradient of a distance–time graph as velocity). Foundation-tier extension: calculate or estimate gradients of graphs (including chords/tangents) and interpret in contexts (distance–time, velocity–time, financial graphs); apply average and instantaneous rate of change concepts in numerical, algebraic and graphical contexts.
Higher-tier only: calculate or estimate areas under graphs and interpret in context (e.g. distance from velocity–time graphs, accumulated change on financial graphs).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Geometric terms: points, lines, planes and perpendicular/parallel
Sub_topics.description: Use correct geometric terminology for 2D/3D contexts: points, lines, line segments, vertices, edges, planes; identify and use parallel and perpendicular lines.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Angle types and triangle labelling conventions
Sub_topics.description: Know angle types: acute, obtuse, right, reflex. Use standard conventions for labelling sides and angles of triangles (e.g. AB, ∠ABC, angle ABC; side a opposite angle A).
Know and use terms: regular polygon; scalene/isosceles/equilateral triangle; quadrilateral, square, rectangle, kite, rhombus, parallelogram, trapezium; pentagon, hexagon, octagon.
Recognise and use terms face, surface, edge, vertex; recognise cube, cuboid, prism, cylinder, pyramid, cone, sphere.
Draw accurate diagrams from written descriptions as required, including labelling and representing given information clearly.
Use a ruler to construct/measure straight lines; use a protractor to construct/measure angles; use compasses to construct circles; apply instrument use within geometric problem solving.
Use x- and y-coordinates in plane geometry problems, including describing/performing transformations of simple shapes on coordinate grids.
Construct the perpendicular bisector of a line segment using ruler and compasses and identify/construct the midpoint of a line segment.
Construct the bisector of an angle formed by two lines using ruler and compasses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Perpendiculars from/to a line (construction) and shortest distance
Sub_topics.description: Construct the perpendicular from a point to a line and the perpendicular to a line at a point; know that the perpendicular distance from a point to a line is the shortest distance from the point to the line.
Apply ruler-and-compass constructions to construct figures and identify loci of points, including in real-world contexts; understand and use the term ‘equidistant’.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Angles at a point and polygon angle reasoning
Sub_topics.description: Know and use angles at a point sum to 360°. Foundation-tier extension: apply angle facts to find unknown angles in rectilinear figures and justify results in simple proofs (including using triangle interior sum 180°). Higher-tier extension: apply these angle properties within more formal geometric proofs.
Know that angles on a line sum to 180° and apply this fact to calculate unknown angles and justify steps in angle-chasing.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Angles in parallel lines (alternate/corresponding) and vertical opposites
Sub_topics.description: Know and use: vertically opposite angles are equal; alternate angles on parallel lines are equal; corresponding angles on parallel lines are equal; apply to find unknown angles and support reasoning.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Angles in polygons (interior/exterior sums, regular polygons)
Sub_topics.description: Derive and use: triangle interior angles sum to 180°; exterior angles of any polygon sum to 360°. Find sum of interior angles of a polygon; find each interior angle of a regular polygon. Use these facts for angle-finding and justification (simple proofs at Foundation; more formal proofs at Higher).

Know properties of isosceles, equilateral and right-angled triangles; give geometrical reasons to justify properties (e.g. base angles in isosceles triangle equal); use facts to find lengths/angles in rectilinear figures and within proofs (more formal at Higher, including links to circle theorems).

Know properties of square, rectangle, parallelogram, trapezium, kite, rhombus; give geometrical reasons; use properties to find lengths/angles and justify steps in proofs (more formal at Higher, including links to circle theorems).
Identify reflection and rotation symmetries of triangles, quadrilaterals and other polygons, including number of lines of symmetry and order of rotational symmetry.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Circle terminology (radius, chord, tangent, sector, segment)
Sub_topics.description: Understand and use circle terms: centre, radius, chord, diameter, circumference; Foundation-tier extension: tangent, arc, sector and segment.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Angle at centre is twice angle at circumference (proof and use)
Sub_topics.description: Higher-tier only: apply and prove the theorem that the angle subtended by an arc at the centre is twice the angle subtended at the circumference (in the same segment).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Angle in a semicircle (proof and use)
Sub_topics.description: Higher-tier only: apply and prove that the angle on the circumference subtended by a diameter is a right angle.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Angles in the same segment (proof and use)
Sub_topics.description: Higher-tier only: apply and prove that two angles in the same segment are equal.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Radius bisects chord iff perpendicular (proof and use)
Sub_topics.description: Higher-tier only: apply and prove that a radius/diameter bisects a chord if and only if it is perpendicular to the chord.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Radius perpendicular to tangent (proof and use)
Sub_topics.description: Higher-tier only: apply and prove that the radius/diameter through the point of contact is perpendicular to the tangent at that point.
Higher-tier only: apply and prove the alternate segment theorem: the angle between a tangent and a chord through the point of contact equals the angle in the opposite segment.
Higher-tier only: apply and prove that opposite angles of a cyclic quadrilateral sum to 180° (are supplementary).
Recognise and know properties of cube, cuboid, prism, cylinder, pyramid, cone and sphere (faces/edges/vertices where applicable; curved surfaces).

Interpret plans and elevations of simple 3D solids. Foundation-tier extension: construct plans and elevations of simple 3D solids and draw representations (e.g. on isometric paper) of solids from plans and elevations.

Reflect a simple shape in a given mirror line; identify the mirror line from a shape and its image under reflection. Foundation-tier extension: identify mirror lines of the form x = a, y = b or y = ±x from a shape and its image.
Rotate a simple shape clockwise or anticlockwise through a multiple of 90° about a given centre of rotation; identify the centre, angle and direction (sense) of a rotation from a shape and its image.
Describe a translation using a column vector and perform a specified translation of a simple shape on a coordinate grid.

Perform a sequence of isometric transformations (reflections/rotations/translations) on a simple shape; describe the resulting overall transformation and identify changes and invariants (e.g. lengths, angles preserved).
Identify congruent triangles. Higher-tier only: prove two triangles are congruent using SSS, ASA, SAS, and RHS congruence criteria.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Using congruence in problems and proofs
Sub_topics.description: Apply congruent triangles to calculate unknown sides/angles and justify results in proofs (e.g. deducing base angles in isosceles triangles).

Higher-tier only: understand vector addition, subtraction and scalar multiplication; use vectors in geometric arguments and proofs (including expressing relationships between points and showing parallelism).
Higher-tier only: represent a 2D vector as a column vector and draw column vectors on square/coordinate grids; use them to describe translations/displacements.
Identify similar triangles. Higher-tier only: prove two triangles are similar (using angle/side proportionality conditions) and apply similarity reasoning.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Enlargement (centre and scale factor incl. negative/fractional)
Sub_topics.description: Enlarge a simple shape from a given centre using a whole-number scale factor; identify the scale factor of an enlargement. Foundation-tier extension: identify the centre and scale factor (including fractional scale factors) and perform enlargement; Higher-tier extension: perform and recognise enlargements with negative scale factors.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Similar shapes: lengths, areas, volumes and scale factors
Sub_topics.description: Compare lengths, areas and volumes using ratio notation and scale factors. Foundation-tier extension: apply similarity to calculate unknown lengths in similar figures; understand relationships between lengths, areas and volumes of similar shapes (e.g. area scale factor is (linear factor)^2; volume scale factor is (linear factor)^3).

Use and convert standard units of measurement for length, area, volume/capacity, mass, time and money. Foundation-tier extension: use and convert standard units in algebraic contexts (e.g. expressing formulas with converted units).

Use and convert simple compound units (e.g. speed, rates of pay, unit pricing). Know and apply speed = distance ÷ time in simple cases. Foundation-tier extension: use and convert other compound units such as density and pressure; know and apply density = mass ÷ volume; use and convert compound units in algebraic contexts.
Use the scale of a map and work with bearings; construct and interpret scale drawings (including converting real distance to map distance and vice versa).
Calculate the perimeter of rectilinear (straight-edged) shapes, including using given side lengths and deducing missing lengths.

Know and apply circumference of a circle: C = 2πr = πd. Foundation-tier extension: calculate arc length of a sector given its angle and radius (proportional to angle/360° or using radians if provided—angles in degrees expected at GCSE).
Apply perimeter methods/formulae to composite 2D shapes (including shapes with circular parts), ensuring correct inclusion/exclusion of internal edges.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Area of a triangle (basic and sine area formula)
Sub_topics.description: Know and apply area of triangle = (1/2) × base × height. Higher-tier extension: know and apply area of triangle = (1/2)ab sin C.
Know and apply area = base × height for parallelograms (including rectangles as a special case).
Calculate the area of a trapezium (using A = (1/2)(a+b)h or equivalent), including identifying parallel sides and perpendicular height.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Area of a circle and sector area
Sub_topics.description: Know and apply area of a circle A = πr^2. Foundation-tier extension: calculate area of a sector given its angle and radius (proportional to angle/360°).
Apply area formulae to calculate the area of composite 2D shapes (including subtracting holes and combining standard regions; may include circular segments/sectors where appropriate at tier).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Surface area and volume of prisms and cylinders
Sub_topics.description: Calculate surface area and volume of cuboids and other right prisms, including cylinders, using appropriate formulae and correct units; handle composite prism calculations where dimensions are given.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Surface area and volume of cones and spheres (formulae given)
Sub_topics.description: Calculate surface area and volume of spheres and cones and simple composite solids; formulae will be provided in assessments; apply accurately with correct substitution and units.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Surface area and volume of pyramids (formula given)
Sub_topics.description: Calculate surface area and volume of a pyramid; volume formula will be given: V = (1/3) × area of base × height; use correctly with appropriate units.

Know, derive and apply Pythagoras’ theorem a^2 + b^2 = c^2 to find lengths in right-angled triangles in 2D. Foundation-tier extension: apply Pythagoras in more complex figures including 3D (e.g. cuboids) requiring multi-step reasoning.

Know and apply sinθ, cosθ and tanθ to find angles and lengths in right-angled triangles in 2D. Foundation-tier extension: apply right-angled trigonometry to more complex figures including 3D contexts; connect to similarity where relevant.
Higher-tier only: know exact values of sinθ and cosθ for θ = 0°, 30°, 45°, 60°, 90°; and exact values of tanθ for θ = 0°, 30°, 45°, 60°; use in exact calculations and reasoning.
Higher-tier only: know and apply the sine rule a/sinA = b/sinB = c/sinC to find unknown lengths and angles in non-right-angled triangles, including ambiguous case awareness as required by questions.

Higher-tier only: know and apply the cosine rule a^2 = b^2 + c^2 − 2bc cosA to find unknown sides/angles in non-right triangles; use with appropriate rearrangement and calculator/non-calculator expectations.
Use the 0–1 probability scale as a measure of likelihood for random events (impossible 0, even chance 0.5, certain 1) and compare likelihoods using this scale.
Record, describe and analyse the relative frequency of outcomes of repeated experiments using tables and frequency trees.
Use relative frequency as an estimate of probability; understand that relative frequencies tend to the theoretical probability as the number of trials increases (law of large numbers concept).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Equally likely outcomes and expected frequency
Sub_topics.description: Calculate probabilities (fractions/decimals) in simple equally likely experiments (coins, dice etc.); apply ideas of randomness and fairness. Foundation-tier extension: calculate probabilities of simple combined events (e.g. rolling two dice and totals); use probabilities to calculate expected numbers of outcomes in repeated experiments (expected frequency = probability × number of trials).

Use tables/grids to list outcomes of single events and simple combinations and calculate theoretical probabilities (e.g. two coin flips; number of orders of letters E, F, G). Foundation-tier extension: use sample spaces for more complex combinations (e.g. sums of two dice; two spinners); recognise when a sample space is the most appropriate representation; Higher-tier extension: select and use the most appropriate diagrams to solve unstructured probability problems where structure is not given.
Use systematic listing strategies to enumerate outcomes. Foundation-tier extension: use the product rule for counting numbers of outcomes of combined events.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Venn diagrams and sets in probability
Sub_topics.description: Use a two-circle Venn diagram to enumerate sets and calculate probabilities. Use simple set notation to describe sets of numbers/objects (e.g. A={even numbers}, B={mathematics learners}, C={isosceles triangles}). Foundation-tier extension: construct Venn diagrams to classify outcomes and calculate probabilities; use set notation to describe sets (including set-builder notation e.g. D={x : 1 < x < 3}, E={x : x is a factor of 280}). Knowledge of intersection (∩), union (∪) and complement notation is not required. Higher-tier extension: construct tree diagrams, two-way tables or Venn diagrams to solve more complex probability problems, including conditional probability; diagram structure may not be given; intersection/union/complement notation still not required.

Use tree diagrams to enumerate outcomes and to record probabilities of successive events; tree frames may be given and may be partly completed; multiply along branches and add across outcomes as appropriate.

Use the addition law for mutually exclusive events; use p(A) + p(not A) = 1. Foundation-tier extension: derive or informally understand and apply p(A or B) = p(A) + p(B) − p(A and B) (general addition rule).

Use tree diagrams and other representations to calculate probabilities of independent and dependent combined events. Foundation-tier extension: understand conditional probability and calculate it from first principles in known contexts (e.g. P(diamond | red) from a 52-card deck). Higher-tier extension: derive/informally understand and apply p(A and B) = p(A given B)p(B); know that A and B are independent iff p(A given B) = p(A).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Populations, samples, random sampling and bias
Sub_topics.description: Define the population in a study; understand the difference between population and sample; infer properties of populations/distributions from a sample. Foundation-tier extension: understand simple random sampling and identify/describe bias in sampling methods.

Interpret and construct charts appropriate to data type: frequency tables, bar charts, pie charts, pictograms for categorical data; vertical line charts for ungrouped discrete numerical data. Foundation-tier extension: interpret multiple and composite bar charts; design tables to classify data; interpret and construct line graphs for time series data and identify trends (including seasonal variation).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Grouped data: histograms and cumulative frequency
Sub_topics.description: Interpret and construct diagrams for grouped data as appropriate: cumulative frequency graphs and histograms, including equal or unequal class intervals; understand frequency density for unequal class widths and interpret areas where relevant.

Calculate mean, mode, median and range for ungrouped data. Foundation-tier extension: find modal class; calculate estimates of range, mean and median for grouped data and understand why these are estimates; describe a population using statistics and make simple comparisons; compare data sets using ‘like for like’ summary values; understand advantages and disadvantages of summary values. Higher-tier extension: estimate mean/median/mode/range/quartiles/interquartile range (IQR) from graphical representations of grouped data; draw and interpret box plots; use median and IQR to compare distributions.
Recognise graphical misrepresentation through incorrect or inconsistent scales, labels, truncated axes, or other distortions; critique and correct representations where possible.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Scatter graphs, correlation and line of best fit
Sub_topics.description: Plot and interpret scatter diagrams for bivariate data; recognise correlation. Foundation-tier extension: interpret correlation in context and distinguish correlation from causation; draw a line of best fit by eye and use it to make predictions; interpolate and extrapolate while acknowledging limitations of these techniques.

Identify an outlier in simple cases; appreciate that outliers may arise from errors or unusual values that do not fit a pattern; recognise outliers on scatter graphs and consider their effect on correlation and predictions.
